intro: Ulmus laevis, commonly known as the European white elm, is a deciduous tree native to Europe and western Asia. It is characterized by its smooth, gray bark and heart-shaped leaves that are typically 5–10 centimeters in length. The tree produces small, yellowish-green flowers in early spring, followed by small, spherical fruits. It is often found in moist, fertile soils along riverbanks and in forests. Due to its ornamental value and historical significance, it has been cultivated in various regions for centuries.
